number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
												The most under-rated game of its time. This game was released shortly after Half-Life 2 and uses the Source engine. When it was first released it had a few bugs and was given horrible reviews, also partially because apparently back then games were expected to have their own custom engine and this one used Source, obviously a problem of the past these days. Within a month the developers had all of those bugs fixed and unfortunately it never got the following it deserved. Perhaps partially due to their releasing it earlier than it should have been.What makes this game special is its melee combat system. There are 3 combat types, melee (broken into sword & shield, sword, daggers, and "other"), archery, and magic. Other first person games have probably done better in archery and maybe magic, although I haven't seen any to that effect. It pains me that other game developers haven't taken this game's mechanics into consideration for their more mainstream titles. Skyrim for example has a system which appears as similar, but ultimately an incomplete and bad copy of DMoM&M. Since if you're reading reviews you probably haven't played it yet, so I'll just say get this game. It's one of the funnest games I've ever experienced, and the replayability is very quality due to its different archetypes, all of which hold their own. Plus, special rewards for exploring the environment fully, a hard mode that doesn't rely on luck to beat, and some crazy weapons that will make you say "I can't wait to go back through and play as someone who can use this" if you resist the urge to look through guides beforehand.When you're done with a few play-throughs and explore each of the unique endings, you should start trying some of the cheats. Using adrenaline telekenesis to toss soldiers (Usually Duncan) 500ft straight up in the air is maybe the funniest thing I've ever seen (or heard) in a game. Also highly recommended is pitting NPCs against each other and seeing who wins. Not cheating, but another one of my favorite things to do is see how many people in Stonehelm I can backstab without anyone noticing.Over a hundred hours of fun can easily be had in this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
 Dark Messiah of Might & Magic Developed by Arkane Studios, the game runs on a modified version of the Source engine; the famed engine that powered Half-Life 2 and its episodes. As much as the world of Ashan is fairly predictable fantasy fare, the game itself plays a lot like your typical Elder Scrolls game.  Physics-based environments are heavily emphasized - far more so than even Bethesda's Oblivion. The puzzles are far better implemented and occur much more often. That said, beyond the physics, few other comparisons to Oblivion hold water. Unsurprisingly, Dark Messiah sticks to a fairly linear plotline. This is no bad thing since, in the space of twelve lengthy chapters, the pacing rarely wanes and you're never stuck pondering your next objective.  Story: The story explores the well-trodden, 'recover the mystical artifact for your mentor who may not be all that he seems' scenario. The heroic player, Sareth, is an orphan raised by the mysterious Phenrig. A magician who fuses Sareth with a decidedly kinky guardian entity, Xana, and vests him with a mission to recover te Skull of Shadows. Of course, like a good book, the story takes a turn for the worse for poor Sareth.The Sareth/Xana relationship is pretty entertaining. She is effectively a jaded voice in Sareth's head, acting as an occasional hint-giver and guiding him on the path to his objectives. Beyond this, there's her oft-spoken allusions towards rewards of a sexual nature and her constant jealousy of Leanna a Witch in training. She is the obvious love interest whom you'll be spending plenty of quality time with by the end of the game. Gameplay It's not surprising in the slightest that the latest iteration of the Might and Magic series draws heavily from multiple sources both book and game alike.Thankfully, the adoption of a first-person perspective makes for a wholly absorbing experience, and the clever integration of several different skills trees for each class and some unique gameplay features keeps Dark Messiah feeling fresh and genuinely exciting years after the games launch. Puzzles-wise, many of the game's more thoughtful and interesting moments are cleverly scripted. A rooftop chase sequence early in the game is fast and just precarious enough to be thrilling without becoming aggrovating. In pursuing a scurrying Gollum-like creature in pursuit of a key quest item, you have mere moments to scramble across awnings and through open windows in a deft combination of platforming skills and problem-solving. Autosaving is very well implemented too - saving at key moments to avoid bouts of severe frustration. Multiplayer In addition to the single-player, there's a decent multiplayer mode to Dark Messiah of Might and Magic, and it's fairly different from the campaign. Here, you can choose from different character classes and go into battle via a few different modes. Deathmatch, team deathmatch, and capture the flag all work as expected.The crusade mode provides a bit more depth than the other modes. This is a humans versus undead mode that uses respawn tickets and control points, similar to something like Warcraft's Arathi Basin battleground or Team Fortress 2's CP_Dustbowl gamemode. The game's multiplayer maps are connected in crusade, so if you win a map, you move one map closer to the opposing team's home base. You also gain experience points and levels in this mode, and each time you level up, you can assign skill points to enhance your abilities like World of Warcraft.You can switch classes each time you spawn, so if you're tired of clashing swords as a warrior, you can switch to a more projectile-based character, like a mage or an archer. Priestesses can heal and resurrect players, and the assassin acts as a standard MMO stealth character. Experience points carry over from one map to the next, provided you stay connected to the same server. Sadly, the only way to connect to servers nowadays is by inputing the IP adress into the command console using the "Connect" command found in most source games... Verdict: 9.4 / 10 	Dark Messiah of Might & Magic is a decent game, it has awesome multiplayer and a decent story filled with content.It may be completed in a matter of 6-12 hours, but the multiplayer is what has kept the game alive since Launch both on Xbox and on PC.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
												I never played this game back in '06, but I picked it up a few days ago and started on Hardcore difficulty. Immediately I was amazed at how fluid the combat felt for such an old game, even surpassing many recent titles of the past few years. You have different attacks for what you choose - magic, sword, staff, bow or daggers and each have their strengths and weaknesses. You can also block, do finishing blows and kick opponents into traps like fire pits, spike pits and off cliffs.This is an Action-RPG in first-person perspective. You are within the Might & Magic universe and it is gloriously wicked. Fight spiders, skeletons, ghouls, goblins, trolls, orcs, zombies, dragons, demons. It is insane. Also insanely hard.You earn skill points to spend on a skill tree, which is where the replayability comes in. There is no new game plus, however I highly recommend you focus on maxing one style of fighting that way you have a reason to play again. I am focusing on upgrading my magic. It is very punishing for mages.10/10With today's standards it still holds up. It holds up hard.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Arkane - the guys that brought You Arx Fatalis, and later Dishonored, probably have the best mappers in the industry. Dark Messiah is a fantasy FPS/slasher, like Heretic 2 or Thief; with a RPG tree and simply crafting. There are 3 main strategies of combat: backstabbing, slicing and roasting. One minus: magic is strong at the beginning, and disappointing as You progress. What it does really well is flow; feeling and pacing - I personally believe it is better, or same as good as in Half Life 2. Vertical maps, rope bow, demon ladies, huge spiders, arson, Kick In The Face® attack... what You would need more. I played it many, many times, and it is still quite fun.

Posted: January 30, 2016
												The storyline is more annoying than anything, though I guess it might not be bad if you've never read a book before. The scenery is pretty cool, but the real reason to play this game is the combat. You feel a lot more in control of the combat than in most similar games, and instead of trying to just get by a group of enemies I find myself playing the same battles again and trying different strategies. The fact that the damage you so is different depending on where on your enemies body you hit (Head shots do massive damage, esp. with a bow.) is great. And the skill purchasing trees as opposed to classes is great too. I wasn't very impressed with most of the magic though.The biggest problem with this game? It is hard to go back to the pathetic combat systems of many other games after so much freedom and control.

												Having played all the other Might and Magic (M&M) titles (Heroes included) I'm ashamed I haven't played this until today. It's definitely a game that fully deserves to bare the title of a M&M game. It's a first person RPG very similar to Dragon's Age (DA), obvioulsy this game is much older than DA thus not as polished and big. number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
												In ages past an RPG either distinguished itself by exceptional story or by great customization. Dark Messiah of Might and Magic does neither of those very well, and I doesn't need to. Dark Messiah's strength is in its gameplay and level-design, its freedom of choice in the completion of challenges set before you. Dark Messiah sports possibly the best melee combat in any First Person game to date and supplements it with a wide variety of environmental interaction.Impaling your enemies on spikes, chopping their limbs off, burning them to a crisp or making them slip on ice, a smart player has full control over the battlefield. Every approach is viable, every environment suited to take on foes in different and interesting ways. You can master Archery, Melee, Stealth and Magic to become a force to be reckonned with.Of course nothing comes without flaws and with Dark Messiah it is unfortunately the engine which often crashes or produces (often hillarious) glitches. Still, if you are looking for a game that will challenge your creativity and mastery, this game is for you.In the realm of content the game provides around 6-8 hours of gameplay time depending on how vigorously you explore the levels and their branching paths and secrets. The story, while nothing to write home about, with a twist telegraphed from miles away, is enjoyable in a corny adventure B-Movie way. Anyone that ever took part in a pen and paper tabletop will enjoy it as a throwback. Furthermore, it never gets in the way, the cinematics are kept to a minimum and never interrupt gameplay for longer than a couple of seconds. Dark Messiah is all about good old fun through gameplay, no carrots on a stick, no grinding and no pretension to be something more than it is.Don't be fooled, Dark Messiah of Might and Magic might be old, but it is classic worth both your time and the price of admission.---Read more game reviews, news and editorials at gatheryourparty.com

content:
Posted: July 25, 2012
												There's something in the back of my head that says Dark Messiah Might and Magic shouldn't be that good for what it is, but I've played through it multiple times and thoroughly enjoyed it each time. The story is decent, and the game handles nicely. The graphics are starting to look a little dated, but they're still passing pretty well considering the game is 6 years old now. Dark Messiah is immensly fun, but I wish they'd given the option to replay through the story on harder difficulty settings while keeping the abilities and gear from completing the game previously - it just feels like you only get to do the really cool stuff towards the end. It's worth replaying the single player to explore the different skill trees, but multiplayer is pretty much not worth bothering with - it doesn't feel at all like the single player, which is pretty disappointing. The bottom line? Buy this for the single player game and you're gonna have a fun hacking, slashing, smashing, and spell casting romp.

												This is a good game with some great ideas. I love kicking and shoving enemies into spiked traps, or off high cliffs. Odd that all those spikey doors are laying about to take advantage of, though.My only complaint: DMMaM does not quite live up to the "play it your way" promise. I tried, really tried, to play as a stealth-based character. There are spots in the game, though, where you must win in arena-style combat. The only way to succeed as a thief was to game the A.I. and kite with arrows. Not realistic, not satisfying.Also, please note, there is no "of" in the title of this game. It drives me crazy how often i see, even at professional game review sites, this game called "Dark messiah OF Might and Magic." WTF?Still, this game is a lot of fun and a good value.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												Dark Messiah of Might & Magic is an awesome First Person RPG filled with tons of action, a decent storyline, great graphics using the Source engine and loaded with fun-filled combat. The campaign is pretty lengthy at ~10 hours long with fully voiced NPCs and cutscenes. As you complete the primary and optional objectives you are given skill points to allocate in 3 different areas and it also allows the player to play a certain playstyle/class: fighter, mage or rogue. The combat is pretty awesome with some in depth actions (for example the sword has multiple ways to attack) and you have the ability to kick enemies off of ledges, into each other or into traps. There are also loads of unique items in the game, such as the all mighty Sword of Dragonclaw and the Lightning Shield and also the Earthfire Sword & Shield combo; most of these items are also hidden in the various secrets areas in every level. For fans of first person games or RPGs this is a must play, it's a polished and truly well made game.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												Fantasy done properly: daggers, swords, bows, magic, creatures, demons, spiders, caves, castles, dragons, orcs, the undead... and bad Demon trying to rule the world.3 classes, various weapons, various skills - all those allow different approach to combat. Set in fantasy world on a quest to save the world from supreme evil - yeah, standard thing, but does job well. Gameplay is great and combat is very satysfying. Game offers multiple playthroughs (3 classes+skill choices) followed by even more playthroughs due to choices made during story (4 endings). In the end you can beat this game many times and experience something new. If you like fantasy setting and playing as mage/warrior/archer/thief (you can mix classes with skills to create a hybrid character) then it is a good choice. You visit caves, castles, towns - generally areas specific to medieval/fantasy worlds. Levels offer diversity in terms of setting and obstacles as well as approach to combat. Sometiemes they have interesting features that change gameplay or are simply quite original (Big Worm as an example).It all sounds like a cliche, but the game leaves a very good impression overall. Too bad it was forgotten. Gameplay/Combat is fluid. Surrounding vary and are never boring. It is a very solid title overall. It feels complete and the theme is consistent.Audio-visuals are strong with this one. Graphics are nice and voice-acting is good. Performance is solid. Music matches the atmosphere.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2012
												What drew me into Dark Messiah was that it seemed like an Elder Scrolls clone without the massive time commitment. In my days of youth, I recall repeatedly playing the demo. When I finally got my hands on a full copy of this game, I was more than enthused to take it for a spin.Dark Messiah boasts a wonderful melee combat system and forces the player to think tactically. Rushing into a room with even two or three enemies will result in certain death. As you level up, you can invest points into your typical RPG attributes: melee, ranged, magic, and stealth combat. Diversity and replayability are certainly present.Unfortunately, the game's difficulty encourages cheap tactics such as kicking enemies over ledges or into traps, resulting in instant kills. The user interface is occasionally unresponsive, making switching weapons or casting spells a royal pain. Furthermore, mages will also find themselves lacking enough hotkeys to fit arsenal.This is a bargain bin game.Grade: C

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												I would recommend this game to both shooter and RPG fans. The gameplay is a bit hard, but it's never boring, if you start playing, you won't stop until the end of the game. While the gameplay of many other RPGs depends on characteristics of your character, player's real skill is very important in DMMM. This game doesn't even have character levels. Graphics are on par with The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim (while the game was made 5 years before Skyrim), sometimes even better, because the game is linear, and developers could spend more resources on improving certain locations; sound effects are pretty good. There are some bugs like getting stuck between objects and inability to jump off a rope when there's another rope nearly, but they're not very critical. The only bad thing about this game is multiplayer. While multiplayer gameplay is fine, it is very laggy. 9/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 21, 2016
Something for all your nefarious (kicking) needsI never knew this game existed until I found it by chance one day ago. Thought I'd pick it up, because it looked interesting, I gathered that the melee combat was good, and I'm currently very curious about first-person melee combat.Nine hours later, it was already evening. I'd binged through most of the whole thing, and had to stop only because of biological needs and because my eyes were stinging. Rarely have I seen them be so bloodshot...This game comes quite close to what I'd like to make, if I had a team of artists at my disposal. The graphics are very pretty, though of course, the game is ten years old at the time of writing of this review, and beauty is in the eyes of the beholder. Still, the HDR lighting in particular makes an astonishing difference, and the whole things looks really nice at maximum quality.The story is... adequate. It's certainly nothing groundbreaking, and I had a feeling that I've already played this game, despite the fact that I never have. That may have been a result of the story.It's worth mentioning that this game feels like some sort of Tomb Raider mixed with the new Thief game (the one from 2014). The protagonist is a gluttonous kleptomaniac with a berry juice addiction, who spends most of his time raiding tombs. Aside from that, we've got demon kings, ancient artefacts, necromancer armies... and, of course, all of it ended with a dragon, as is standard for the budget fantasy genre.It really does remind me of a budget fantasy film... But I really love that sort of thing, so I enjoyed it.I should also say that the "big twist" of the story actually caught me by surprise. I wasn't expecting that to happen.It's also got a voiced protagonist (though no dialogue choices), something which I very much prefer, so extra points for that.The characters are standard - nothing quite memorable in that department - and the voice acting is... delicious. It's not "great", but I like it. You can guess whether the character is good or evil based on voice alone. Ain't that a good thing?The gameplay is quite interesting as well. The melee combat is quite well executed, though magic and switching between the two is slughtly clunky by today's standards (or at least my standards). As usual, the player is presented with different playstyle options: sword-and-board combat, archery, magic and stealth. However, you can always do all of them, and aren't necessarily limited to one, which is very nice - some situations are naturally better solved with some tools rather than others.I personally went for a build that emphasised stealth and marksmanship. They both start off pretty weak, but stealth ends up completely broken in the endgame (Remember Chameleon 100% in Oblivion, anyone? It's sort of like this, but with actual backstab mechanics that aren't dreadful).Furthermore, enemies are prone to parrying most of your swings and dealing too much damage to you, so direct combat is more effort than necessary.I can't not mention the kick. Kicking is your best friend, because of the point above, and because there's precarious ledges and walls of spikes everywhere. When it works properly, you can propel enemies backward, and literally send them flying. It feels extremely satisfying. If you like the power fantasy type of games - Far Cry 3/4's broken takedown mechanics come to mind - then you'll probably enjoy the combat here... Kicking, that is. Note that it's not as overpowered as the knife in said Far Cries, because you can still die in three hits, and your kicking stamina is limited, but it's still pretty enjoyable.The sound is fantastic. Except the thundering footsteps that are loud even when you're supposed to be sneaking. But aside from that, I really enjoyed the sound. The ambience is very atmospheric when it wants to be, and some combat tracks were brilliant. Sounds in general were also on par.Some other things worth mentioning:- The goblins in this game are great, and I absolutely loved them. Their banter is hilarious, including the in-combat quotes, and slauthering them was so fun that I'm slightly worried to admit it. Unfortunately, there was too little goblins throughout.- The first-person full-body-awareness thing this game has going on is sometimes exceptionally glitchy, but it's not fatal. Still, it's a bit awkward to have your knees clip through your face when you're running up a steep staircase... but fortunately, that rarely happens.Conclusion: May I have some more, please?Dark Messiah of Might and Magic is a well-made, if not very polished game. It's aged quite well (your opinions may vary), except a few things that I'd personally change, mostly related to the inventory.The combat is satisfying, and the story isn't too bad. I thoroughly enjoyed it, and would have very much liked it if additional campaigns or expansions existed.I thoroughly recommend it. It's worth at least a single playthrough, if not more, and the ratio of value to price is big. I got my copy for less than £3.50, so I can't complain on that front.Final rating: 7.5 Pao-Kais out of 10 Pao-Kais.

												What drew me into Dark Messiah was that it seemed like an Elder Scrolls clone without the massive time commitment. In my days of youth, I recall repeatedly playing the demo. When I finally got my hands on a full copy of this game, I was more than enthused to take it for a spin.Dark Messiah boasts a wonderful melee combat system and forces the player to think tactically. Rushing into a room with even two or three enemies will result in certain death. As you level up, you can invest points into your typical RPG attributes: melee, ranged, magic, and stealth combat. Diversity and replayability are certainly present.Unfortunately, the game's difficulty encourages cheap tactics such as kicking enemies over ledges or into traps, resulting in instant kills. The user interface is occasionally unresponsive, making switching weapons or casting spells a royal pain. Furthermore, mages will also find themselves lacking enough hotkeys to fit arsenal.This is a bargain bin game.Grade: C

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2012
												For a game I've only recently heard about, this is one of my favorite games of the summer. The combat's far beyond anything you'd find in most RPGs, foregoing a weak-hitting numbers game in favor of physical, visceral combat. The kick button alone gets a lot of mileage from varied combat scenarios. A nice range of weapons, plenty of magic, and varied character progression give this game's 10-12 hour campaign a hefty amount of replay value. The story's forgettable, but the combat, presentation, and cool level design more than make up for it.The developer's currently working on Dishonored; if that looks good to you, then you'll probably appreciate this.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 21, 2016
Something for all your nefarious (kicking) needsI never knew this game existed until I found it by chance one day ago. Thought I'd pick it up, because it looked interesting, I gathered that the melee combat was good, and I'm currently very curious about first-person melee combat.Nine hours later, it was already evening. I'd binged through most of the whole thing, and had to stop only because of biological needs and because my eyes were stinging. Rarely have I seen them be so bloodshot...This game comes quite close to what I'd like to make, if I had a team of artists at my disposal. The graphics are very pretty, though of course, the game is ten years old at the time of writing of this review, and beauty is in the eyes of the beholder. Still, the HDR lighting in particular makes an astonishing difference, and the whole things looks really nice at maximum quality.The story is... adequate. It's certainly nothing groundbreaking, and I had a feeling that I've already played this game, despite the fact that I never have. That may have been a result of the story.It's worth mentioning that this game feels like some sort of Tomb Raider mixed with the new Thief game (the one from 2014). The protagonist is a gluttonous kleptomaniac with a berry juice addiction, who spends most of his time raiding tombs. Aside from that, we've got demon kings, ancient artefacts, necromancer armies... and, of course, all of it ended with a dragon, as is standard for the budget fantasy genre.It really does remind me of a budget fantasy film... But I really love that sort of thing, so I enjoyed it.I should also say that the "big twist" of the story actually caught me by surprise. I wasn't expecting that to happen.It's also got a voiced protagonist (though no dialogue choices), something which I very much prefer, so extra points for that.The characters are standard - nothing quite memorable in that department - and the voice acting is... delicious. It's not "great", but I like it. You can guess whether the character is good or evil based on voice alone. Ain't that a good thing?The gameplay is quite interesting as well. The melee combat is quite well executed, though magic and switching between the two is slughtly clunky by today's standards (or at least my standards). As usual, the player is presented with different playstyle options: sword-and-board combat, archery, magic and stealth. However, you can always do all of them, and aren't necessarily limited to one, which is very nice - some situations are naturally better solved with some tools rather than others.I personally went for a build that emphasised stealth and marksmanship. They both start off pretty weak, but stealth ends up completely broken in the endgame (Remember Chameleon 100% in Oblivion, anyone? It's sort of like this, but with actual backstab mechanics that aren't dreadful).Furthermore, enemies are prone to parrying most of your swings and dealing too much damage to you, so direct combat is more effort than necessary.I can't not mention the kick. Kicking is your best friend, because of the point above, and because there's precarious ledges and walls of spikes everywhere. When it works properly, you can propel enemies backward, and literally send them flying. It feels extremely satisfying. If you like the power fantasy type of games - Far Cry 3/4's broken takedown mechanics come to mind - then you'll probably enjoy the combat here... Kicking, that is. Note that it's not as overpowered as the knife in said Far Cries, because you can still die in three hits, and your kicking stamina is limited, but it's still pretty enjoyable.The sound is fantastic. Except the thundering footsteps that are loud even when you're supposed to be sneaking. But aside from that, I really enjoyed the sound. The ambience is very atmospheric when it wants to be, and some combat tracks were brilliant. Sounds in general were also on par.Some other things worth mentioning:- The goblins in this game are great, and I absolutely loved them. Their banter is hilarious, including the in-combat quotes, and slauthering them was so fun that I'm slightly worried to admit it. Unfortunately, there was too little goblins throughout.- The first-person full-body-awareness thing this game has going on is sometimes exceptionally glitchy, but it's not fatal. Still, it's a bit awkward to have your knees clip through your face when you're running up a steep staircase... but fortunately, that rarely happens.Conclusion: May I have some more, please?Dark Messiah of Might and Magic is a well-made, if not very polished game. It's aged quite well (your opinions may vary), except a few things that I'd personally change, mostly related to the inventory.The combat is satisfying, and the story isn't too bad. I thoroughly enjoyed it, and would have very much liked it if additional campaigns or expansions existed.I thoroughly recommend it. It's worth at least a single playthrough, if not more, and the ratio of value to price is big. I got my copy for less than £3.50, so I can't complain on that front.Final rating: 7.5 Pao-Kais out of 10 Pao-Kais.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2013
												I admit, Dark Messiah came as sort of a surprise for me. Absolutely fantastic level design that actually supports all three viable play styles (combat-magic-stealth) in equal measure, and first-person melee combat which is still one of the best ever made combined with lack of incessant hand holding inherent to video games these days - all come together in one amazing package that's only somewhat tarnished by its wonky AI and, at times, signature Source Engine animation clunkiness. Also, "chewing the scenery" doesn't even BEGIN to describe game's voice acting.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2013
												After replaying this initial source engine gem from 2006 it was VERY evident that Arkane Studios had basically overhauled the overall theme, setting, characters etc for Dishonored (Its in my very very fond games forever list) every ability nearly (magic) is straight out of the design works of this or that game; Arkane both uses DARK VISION (may have gotten the name wrong) as the first tier of that tree; it has Stealth Elements based on manouvering around; straight magic based combat (figure using Rats, or various combinations of them) and then the Sword and board (or whatever weapon you pick up) having bow and arrow feels like the crossbow in dishonored. A crossbow even more. If you use a shield ofcourse you can block - but hesterically enough 6 years prior to dishonored if you are using daggers or just a sword if you end up hitting at the same time; the same type of button mash prompt will apear to see who gets the "break" on the sword fight - ALSO same system is used to block an enemies weapon blows by hitting right click with a 1hsword / dagger by quickly parry blocking (same animation style as in dishonore) - Its basically Dishonored in the Might and Magic universe; without the ability to use the spell "Blink". :). That is a good thing!

content:
Posted: November 3, 2013
												This game is not like other games. Though the classes are lacking with only the assassin, wizard, and warrior, the game has an excelent use of making the player pay attention to his surroundings. For example, there is a platform with two weak beams supporting it. There is an enemy below it that you have just lured. You must break the beams, and the platform will fall resulting in the enemy to fall down and become vulnerable. There is much more to discover when you play this game. Like secrets you can find and mini bosses. The armor and weapons in the game are great, because they have different properties and damage ratings. To end it off, this game has many levels and lots of content for many hours! Even if you beat the game you can play from another class and it will feel like another game! These are just some of the reasons for getting this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												I immediately thought about this game as my "Test of time" award pick. I have bought it when it came out and loved it, then I played it a few years ago to "master" it and it was still amazing. Few months ago I had some free time so I decided to come back and play a bit - which ended in a full playthrough. What makes this game stand the test of time so well is its amazingly satisfying combat system - especially on higher difficulty setting. It's brutal, fast paced, it requires you to use the enviroment and look out for your stamina. And I have to mention again - it's extremely satisfying. When you fight off a ghoul pack... dancing around like crazy, kicking, parrying, making the best out of opportunities to attack, trading off space around you for some time to regain stamina, trying not to get surrounded and looking for a good place to attack from... and then its over. Then you realise it was only a few seconds since the fight started and now you find yourself surrounded by corpes. The feeling is glorious. I will surely play this game again in some time.*MILD SPOILER* My favorite fight is the one where you enter the city, you find Duncan and then you have to fight a necromancer and a bunch of ghouls. Trying to keep Duncan alive in this fight on the high difficulty is so madly difficult, ghouls kill him in one hit if he doesn't manage to block and there are few waves of them, coming at you from different angles. It's very frustrating but also very satisfying whenever you find a way to get a bit closer to keeping Duncan alive. I should probably say that you don't have to keep him alive and it has 0 influence on the story... It actually seems like the SHOULD die here (your character says a line when he dies), but if you are determined enough, he can be saved. I mean... we like challenges, right? :D

content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												I played this game before it came on Steam, and I had a blast.I bought this game when it came out on Steam, and I have been having a hell of a good time all over again. It's not the most gorgeous game, it's about on-par with Half-Life 2 (fun fact: they're on the same engine). The RPG elements aren't the most deep, and skill points are gained at set points throughout the game, some of which are missable. The story is entirely ignorable.  Weapons and armor are only acquired through finding them in the world. It's mostly linear.But you can kick people off cliffs. You can kick people into fires and watch as they struggle to limp over to a source of water before you kick them in and kill them while they're down. You can kick people into spikes. You can kick people into weak structural supports, causing barrels and boxes and whatnot to fall onto their allies, killing them. Your kick is one of the greatest weapons of all time, and it is unbelievably satisfying to use throughout the entire game. I've never had so much fun with first-person fantasy combat in my life.I give it 4/5 kicks. Buy this game.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2012
												I never really gave Dark Messiah a chance back when it was first released. I bought it, played it for maybe 10 minutes and then closed it. I don't know why, because I started playing this again recently and it was pretty good for a game released in 2006. The graphics still hold up (well, mostly) to this day and the gameplay works alright as well, with some minor flaws. These flaws aren't actually flaws at all. It's just that we've been spoiled with games that do most of these 'flaws' better. For example, walking around, and especially jumping over obstacles, feels very wooden. Same goes for the combat. Switching between weapons and spells isn't as fluent when compared to, let's say, Skyrim. Now I can't fault a 6 year old game for not being up-to-date, but it does throw you out of the experience from time to time.I really should've played this earlier, because it was seriously pretty good.I do wonder if Bulletstorm got its inspiration from this game though... ?[Rating: 80/100]

content:
Posted: July 17, 2013
												The game is based on Source engine so it makes it Half-Life 2 with magic and stuff.If you spend your learning points right way you get lots of weapons — grenade launcher (Fireball spell), flamethrower (oh, I meant to say Inferno spell), the gravity gun (Telekinesis), and unlimited amount of first aid kits (Heal spell). Ammo (mana) regenerates slowly. Of course you can learn sword fighting or stealth instead and playing this way is much easier, but being mage is more fun. They also put in your head hot (literally) demon girl which works like Infolink from Deus Ex. You have to fight helicopters (dragons), armored vehicles (cyclops), combine soldiers (guards). There is even antlions level (spiders). If you are not comfortable with spiders, install No-Spider mod.I feel like the game is a little bit underrated. It's interesting despite being absolutely linear. There is multiplayer mode but it doesn't function anymore.Oh, and by the way, game adds French AZERTY keyboard layout into system settings. It looks like developers are not going to fix this bug, so don't forget to delete it after completing the game.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												Embrace the power of the Dark Side! Back in the days, this title was a good example of a well-crafted action RPG created with Source Engine. It was both gameplay-rich and storytelling-wise, with a tech potential of the Source engine at it's finest for that time period.It's not an open-world game, but it does give you a choice. You have a choice to craft your own hero, choosing your path through the storyline set in one of the HoMM worlds. You could become a powerful wizard and unleash doom at your foes or stick to the shadows and play with prey. Or you could pick an axe, and start to wreck everything in your way in blazing havoc. Choice is yours.I recommend this game for all fantasy fanboys out there because it's now the living classics and it'll totally be worth your time. It's missing Steamworks features, though, but I wonder how nice would have been an HD remaster!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												This is a first person action RPG with very enjoyable combat and well-designed levels. It may look a bit aged and the story is nothing to write home about, but it's still good fun.You can make the protagonist Sareth a fighter, mage or rogue-type character, or a combination thereof. Depending on the skills selected, he will be able to use different equipment and/or spells. But for most of the game, the terrain and your right boot will be your most powerful weapons: kicking enemies into fires or spikes or off ledges is great fun and highly effective, as is getting them crushed by falling objects. While it might seem exploity, the environments are intentionally designed so you can decimate your enemies like this - and it still makes you feel like a clever ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ when you do. The occasional boss creatures are also pretty cool. Levels are long and very well made, with plenty of secrets to find, The only real downside here is that the fast attacks in close combat feel a bit lacking in substance.The story is basically your standard "young apprentice ignorant of his shadowy origins embarks upon quest" type thing. It's not badly done but very predictable. What few narrative choices there are make next to no difference at all, choosing a different playstyle changes the game more.I cannot say anything about the multiplayer as I haven't played it, but I find the game to be worth getting regardless.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												The M&M series is primarily either an old-school, pen-and-paper style dungeon crawler, or a card game. Meanwhile, Dark Messiah is an oddity; it's a first-person action RPG in the Source engine, of all things! Picture Half-Life 2 with swords and sorcery instead of guns and robots, and you'll have a good idea of what this game plays like. Going into this title, I did not expect much. I knew it was from Arkane Studios, the same folks who delivered the excellent Dishonored, but all the same I was not prepared to fall in love with the game.The StoryMost certainly Dark Messiah's weakest aspect. You play as Sareth, an apprentice serving under the wizard Menelag. Your master has sent you to deliver some sort of artifact to a friend in a far off city, but has transported a woman into your conciousness to be your guide for mysterious reasons. Xana is pretty much a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ version of Cortana from Halo. You'll either tolerate her character, or outright despise her. Once you actually get to your destination, stuff hits the fan and you're thrust into a campaign to defeat an evil Necromancer. There are quite a few plot twists along the way. The biggest will probably be obvious to you, but I can guarantee there are plenty of left-field ones. The question is... will you even care enough to, well, care about what happens? 6/10The GameplayAhhh, now here's Dark Messiah's shining beacon of awesomeness. I'm going to be blunt about this one, straight out of the gate: Dark Messiah has the greatest first-person combat I've experienced in a game. The guys at Arkane are wizards when it comes to first-person animations; everything is incredibly silky smooth and satisfying to witness and interact with. As you progress through the game, you'll be rewarded Skill Points which you can then distribute as you please through two skill trees. There's no skill that will drastically change up how you play; just some generic "More HP" or "Slightly Bigger Fireball". Still, it works. You can also get some skill points by finding certain secret objectives within the world.Dark Messiah's level structure is not unlike Doom or Quake... Littered with clever secrets (Some I didn't find until my fifth or so playthrough!) filled with special loot like new armors and weapons. Using either a Sword & Shield, Dual-Daggers, Staves, Bows, or Magic, you'll slice and dice and stab and smash and burn and freeze and electrocute your way through hordes of Mercenaries, Orcs, Giant Spiders, Undead, and more. Though you can mash your attack button, that is rarely effective. The true combat is found using the various styles of power attacks. Not unlike the system found in Elder Scrolls, you'll preform different attacks based on which direction you are moving. From vertical swipes to long reaching stabs to hard-hitting slashes, you'll need to use every available move to defeat the very clever Orcs later on. Swords are nimble; the all-around weapon. They're capable of parrying foes, and you can even disarm by power-attacking while aiming at the hand. Daggers are lightning fast. They chop up foes before they can get a swing in, and they are capable of instant kills against unaware and fleeing enemies. Staves lack damage, but in smart hands they are the most powerful in the game. They can strike multiple foes at once, and blows to the head almost always stun instantly, leaving the foe extremely vulnerable to being kicked off their feet and into traps and the like. Bows work like you'd expect; headshots instantly kill unaware enemies. Once you get the skill that makes you draw faster and a secret unlimited quiver, it's possible to go bow-only, most definitely.Magic requires a lot of skill to use effectively. Sure, you have your standard fireballs and lightning bolts and freeze spells, but in my experience it is just too difficult to use solely these in combat. You'll need to be crafty; turn enemies against each other with a mind-control spell, shrink enemies to the size of mice, and lay traps near instant-killing spike-walls in the environment. About a third of the way through the game, you'll find the Rope Bow. Truly an inventive tool that I would adore seeing in another game. Near useless in combat, this weapon is instead used to navigate the environment; firing at any wooden structure above you will release a dangling rope you can climb and jump from! This one simple tool drastically changes up the level structure from there-on, and gives room for some dastardly secret nooks and crannies.Admittedly, it does take quite a while to get used to how the game works. But I guarantee you... when it all clicks, you'll be saying "Holy smokes! This is gosh-dang-diddly-dum AWESOME!" 10/10The Art and the SoundIf you've seen any sort of high fantasy movie, show, comic, or game, you've seen everything in Dark Messiah before. There's nothing visually that is truly original or outstanding. Admittedly, the super weapons later on have some great designs and one of the final levels is a big palette cleanser after hours of trudging through a boring ol' cave system. The environment, the enemies... it's all generic as possible. Thankfully, the sound is a fair bit better. The clang of metal against metal and swooshes of air as swords tear through it are top-notch and really bring a little extra bit of immersion. You'll probably get sick fast of the early Mercenary enemies who seem to always begin a fight with "Hey, pal!", but the later gruffness of Orcs and Goblins and the like feel a fair bit more threatening. 8/10The ReplayabilityBetween the many different styles of equipment available, the extremely harsh skill point limit, and the myriad of secrets to be found in every corner, you'll definitely want to play this beast more than once. The average first playthrough will probably take 12-15 hours. There are multiple endings, but trust me; you won't be replaying just to see these. The addictiveness of the combat is far more a reason to do so than the plot. 9/10In SummaryDark Messiah came out in 2006, and I played it in 2014. I was WOWed by it, and found myself playing it over five times before getting bored. I legitimately count it among one of my favorite games now. Well worth the low price of admission these days!Story: 6/10Gameplay: 10/10Art and Sound: 8/10Replayability: 9/10Total: 8.3/10

content:
Posted: December 9, 2010
												Dark Messiah is one of those games that I enjoyed immensely but people in general seemed to dislike. It probably doesnt do the other Might and Magic games justice (I wouldn't know), but it is a solid game in itself with good melee combat (for me, probably the best yet), agreeable graphics and lots of fun places to explore.The game lets you pick your own path and places to reach with its lovable rope-arrows, which -for those that have played them- works exactly like the rope arrows in Thief 1 & 2. The exploration is encouraged by the game designers and you will often find awesome stuff (like a homage to the Thief series as an example) lying about in crazy places.So if you are an old Thief Fan that love exploration and getting to places you werent mean to be in(tm), this is probably a game for you. If youre just on the lookout for some fantasy melee (or range/magic) action with optional stealth, this is also probably a game for you.Just dont abuse the kick, it spoils the fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2011
												Well, this is certainly the most impressive use of the Source engine I've ever seen. Pretty cool game. It's not what you think it is. This is not an open-ended adventure game a la Elder Scrolls. This is an "on-rails" first-person hack-and-slash akin to Half Life.Not to say that's bad; it's just not what I expected. There's not a lot of exploring to do. Some, but not much. There are secret places you might not find, but they rarely contain anything really valuable (just a couple extra potions usually). The graphics are pretty, the combat system is really, really cool.The one bad thing is that you spend in-game time to perform meta-game tasks. For example, the game doesn't pause while you're in your backpack or re-doing your hotbar. So if you get in a fight and that spell you want isn't already bound, you're taking some damage while you open your backpack and drag the spell's icon onto your hotbar.Good game, but don't expect Oblivion. It's Half-Life with swords.

Hell, you can do all this or a combination off everything, and even more! Seriously! What more could you want?!

												This game has the best first-person RPG combat I've ever played. Apparently it had a bunch of bugs when it first launched or something...I don't know, but I got it recently on a sale, and I haven't seen any bugs. Think Oblivion - the open world + way better combat + source engine physics + more focused, linear storyline. I don't understand why some people think that a linear story is always a bad thing. Its simply a different style. The biggest benefit is that the developers get to focus on each part more, making a more involved and polished experience.

Posted: September 16, 2012
												I would say this is one of the best action based rpg's out there, it's my personal favorite next to Fable, and even better than Oblivion and Skyrim, the combat system is better and the level system and skill tree is more enjoyable as well..... The only complaints I had was that it felt short and the ending of the story was strangely abrupt, but the shortness of the game is easily made up by it's re playability of different skill trees and different difficulty settings. The game also has a multiplayer and it's fun but there is rarely anyone that plays.  It's one of my favorites because leveling systems and combat mechanics for me is really important as opposed to the Elder Scrolls series which seems to skip over that, like I said it's kind of like a WoW version of Fable, if your into orcs and dragons and a fun leveling system than you wont regret getting this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2012
												A first-person action/adventure game which eschews player levels for skill points awarded based on progress through the game rather than kills (except bosses). Allows combinations of the three combat styles common in games (warrior, rogue, mage), but the more skillful player will use their environment to greatest advantage. The world is littered with physics objects which may be used to hurt, disorient, trip, or impale your enemies. Shove your foes into the fire, or use oil to bring the fire to them. If they are foolish enough to wander near a high ledge, give them a kick and let gravity do the work for you. Take advantage of traps or unsafe building equipment, which could hurt them just as well as you.If you're not the type to get your hands dirty, charm the most powerful foe and watch them fight amongst each other. Or sneak by them, you need not be the grim reaper in this world, as foes are merely obstacles in your path, not the goal.Would you embrace your destiny or fight it?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2012
												Don't be confused by the name. This is no turn-based RPG. It's first-person action all the way with just a sprinking of RPG progression.Dark Messiah's single player has been the only first-person "shooter" I've played that brought back memories of the old Jedi Knight games. It's not just a rollicking adventure, but it offers very distinct playstyles. The stealth mechanics are good enough to satisfy a fan of the Thief games. Some of the spells are brutal and make you feel like a truly powerful mage. And those who prefer fighting will enjoy the novel-yet-effective experience of throwing furniture at enemies and kicking them off edges or into spikes.Get this game if you're missing over-the-top shooters of old, like Jedi Knight or Duke Nukem, or if you liked the combat in Skyrim but longed for something MORE.

												Easily one of my favourite RPG titles, not for what it does but for what it doesn't. Linearity so I always feel the action instead of having to "admire the scenery" for 20 minutes in between each quest. No shops so I don't have to♥♥♥♥♥♥about hoarding every item that gets dropped to sell on. Best of all no boring side quests! number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2011
												What makes this game revolutionary and yet fall short in ratings? Many complain about the linearity and shortness of the game. The linear aspect made this game come off more as an adventure novel and enhanced the experience. A game that if polished, it could have deserved more. The combat system of this game is revolutionary, yet enemies are too overpowered thus making fighting repetitious and rather boring. However, through the eyes of a game developer the idea was genius and sadly overlooked. If the same system was applied to other source games, it would only enhance the gaming experience, allowing more control. The storyline has a total of three endings, yet the horrible ending suffers continuity issues. Despite the game suffering from bugs and some questionable design, the modern has advanced so far that this game runs rather smoothly. Revolutionary in combat and often overlooked, I recommend gamers to play this solely through the eyes as someone interested in game development.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2012
												Probably the best 10 dollar game you will ever play. The combat is gripping and the story (so far) is compelling. Truely a hidden gem. The graphics and animations do look slightly dated as it is a six year old game, but they are better than what you get in tes: oblivion as far as I can tell (with much better combat and a story that doesn't suck). It does run in 1920x1080 with a 16:9 aspect ratio which is a plus. However, you will get slight pixelation in the cut scenes due to this (as should be expected for older titles). Final disclaimer, although I compared it to tes it is not open world. It is similar to a shooter really (or simply a classic rpg). You begin each "chapter" of the game on a level and play it through. Your items and "spec" stick with you throughout the game though, and although it plays like this the game doesn't feel linear. The objectives are not insanely straight forward and there multiple paths to completing each one.

Can we can have a sequel please?

content:
Posted: December 9, 2010
												Dark Messiah is one of those games that I enjoyed immensely but people in general seemed to dislike. It probably doesnt do the other Might and Magic games justice (I wouldn't know), but it is a solid game in itself with good melee combat (for me, probably the best yet), agreeable graphics and lots of fun places to explore.The game lets you pick your own path and places to reach with its lovable rope-arrows, which -for those that have played them- works exactly like the rope arrows in Thief 1 & 2. The exploration is encouraged by the game designers and you will often find awesome stuff (like a homage to the Thief series as an example) lying about in crazy places.So if you are an old Thief Fan that love exploration and getting to places you werent mean to be in(tm), this is probably a game for you. If youre just on the lookout for some fantasy melee (or range/magic) action with optional stealth, this is also probably a game for you.Just dont abuse the kick, it spoils the fun.

content:

												Good game at a good price. First, it's not open like Oblivion. But the degree of polish and detail is something you can't find in a massive world game. You can build your character as you like, and there are always many routes to take to complete the objectives. Single-player has a good story, and really breaks from the cliche RPG stories. Multiplayer has great potential, as you can improve skills by completing tasks. Combat is excellent in all aspects, and I recommend the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												Dark Messiah has been out for more than a few years now, but the game still provides a solid single-player experience. The story may not be that engaging, but the combat is fun and allows you to finish the game in a number of ways: you can either develop yourself as an assassin, a mage, just go for a hardcore berserker approach or develop for some sort of hybrid. The nice thing is that all of these feel like they are actually viable and fun options.The game was based on the Source engine, meaning it also uses the physics made popular by Half-Life 2 to its fullest, admittedly even going a little overboard on it sometimes (or those orcs sure love having dem dere spikey racks all over the place). The use of the Source engine also means that Dark Messiah´s graphics have aged quite well.All in all, a good 8/10.

												What I liked about Dark Messiah was the fear of the enemy's attack when on the hardest settings.  I found myself running away from enemies all the time. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2011
												MM Dark Messiah is one of the most forgotten and unappreciated gems in the role-playing genre. The game breaks from the classic Might & Magic style from a long open world rpg to a linear action focused rpg and it does so beautifully. The game is short for a rpg lasting only 6 hours or so, but in that time you will fight epic interactive battles with everything from Orcs, Cyclops, Liches, Wyverns and much more. The gameplay of Dark Messiah is the best in the entire library of rpg's, and the game rewards creative fast paced combat with tons of ways of hilariously killing your enemies. The storyline is good scripted, good voice acting and multi choice ending. It's in many ways better than Oblivion, Dragon Age and Mass Effect. To me Dark Messiah represent the last of the great action games like Heretic, Hexen, Quake and Doom.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												This game got dumped on by a lot of critics when it came out, and not without reason. Magic is gimpy, and the most powerful tactic by far is kicking dudes into pointy things. However, the fact remains that no game has ever made first person melee combat feel so good or so smooth, not even zeno clash. It's also one of the few games that effectively combines action and stealth gameplay, so that both approaches seem worthwhile, even using both if you've spent your skillpoints appropriately. Just do yourself a favor and don't bother with hardcore mode. It makes all humanoid enemies and possibly spiders invincible unless you knock them down and hit them with a coup de grace, which makes combat incredible tedious.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2012
												A first-person action/adventure game which eschews player levels for skill points awarded based on progress through the game rather than kills (except bosses). Allows combinations of the three combat styles common in games (warrior, rogue, mage), but the more skillful player will use their environment to greatest advantage. The world is littered with physics objects which may be used to hurt, disorient, trip, or impale your enemies. Shove your foes into the fire, or use oil to bring the fire to them. If they are foolish enough to wander near a high ledge, give them a kick and let gravity do the work for you. Take advantage of traps or unsafe building equipment, which could hurt them just as well as you.If you're not the type to get your hands dirty, charm the most powerful foe and watch them fight amongst each other. Or sneak by them, you need not be the grim reaper in this world, as foes are merely obstacles in your path, not the goal.Would you embrace your destiny or fight it?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2012
												Don't be confused by the name. This is no turn-based RPG. It's first-person action all the way with just a sprinking of RPG progression.Dark Messiah's single player has been the only first-person "shooter" I've played that brought back memories of the old Jedi Knight games. It's not just a rollicking adventure, but it offers very distinct playstyles. The stealth mechanics are good enough to satisfy a fan of the Thief games. Some of the spells are brutal and make you feel like a truly powerful mage. And those who prefer fighting will enjoy the novel-yet-effective experience of throwing furniture at enemies and kicking them off edges or into spikes.Get this game if you're missing over-the-top shooters of old, like Jedi Knight or Duke Nukem, or if you liked the combat in Skyrim but longed for something MORE.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												Here's a basic review about this game:Story: 7.5/10 - A bit lackluster, but it gets the job done.  Given that most of the game involves action there isn't as much need for an in-depth story, though it would have been appreciated.  Lots came in the form of snippets in books, which have copies throughout in case if you miss one.  Pretty decent overall, though not enough to really draw you in fully.Gameplay: 10/10 - There's a reason why TotalBiscuit has sworn by this game.  The combat is amazing.  Makes me wish that more RPGs, such as Skyrim, could have just copied and pasted these mechanics into their games instead of try to make their own from scratch.  The use of rope arrows to help climb up surfaces was a nice touch, and the game is loaded with secrets...speccing in alertness early on will be a move you won't regret.Dialogue: 6/10 - With story, this one was kind of lackluster, though thankfully it was enough to keep some of my attention.  The dialogue between the two potential 'love interests' in the game was absolutely ridiculous at times.Art Style: 7.9/10 - You can definitely tell it is a Source engine game by simple nature of the fact that everything is nice and gritty.  Does remind one a bit too much like Half Life 2 in that regard, but it is forgivable; after all, this is the only actual RPG that uses the Source engine with any form of credibility.Lighting: 4/10 - Probably more frustrating than some of the puzzles.  I had to fiddle with the effects because everything was too dark.  Giving the player the ability to use Darkvision from the get-go put me in a position where I thought the dark rooms were a mechanic rather than a flaw on the settings.  This, however, is mostly a Source engine problem and I couldn't expect them to provide me with a flashlight, so despite my griping it's a forgivable feature.Overall experience: 9/10 - Definitely will be playing this game again, but more importantly this game has left me with some high expectations for any planned followups if/when they happen.  One thing is for sure though; this game has given me new appreciation for the Source Engine, and makes me wish that Dark Messiah wasn't the only RPG available on said engine.-Kerian

content:
Posted: October 11, 2011
												Probably the first action-RPG I've ever played with a truly interactive combat environment.  Imagine being in a swordfight along the edge of a cliff, then reveling as a swift kick results in that guard you were dueling with falling hundreds of feet off the edge... to his DOOM! Or... fighting with some foes, you spot some spikes protruding from the side of a wall in the room. With a nice kick, that orc you were fighting falls onto the spikes, getting impaled on them! There are a few other things I could add, but you get the idea. The game also has some pretty nice combat animations for a first person RPG. Doing a power-stroke with your sword, some of these animations can involve driving your sword clear through the gut of your foes, then kicking their corpse off the blade with a well placed kick, resulting in showers of blood. Uses the Source engine.Warning: though fun, the game is EXTREMELY buggy. Fortunately it's also cheap! (And imo worth it at this price).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2012
												Just wow is this game a hidden gem. Dark Messiah is about an apprentice to a powerful wizard who finds he's more than just an apprentice. Powered by Source, this game's visuals are amazing for the time it was made. What really separates this from other RPGs is the physics and controls. Using the source engine, enemies are flung around like ragdolls. There's all kinds of booby traps and other devices to help you fight enemies. Depending on which buttons you push (forward, back, left, right) determines which way you swing your weapon or which type of attack you use. It comes out so smooth and intuitively it's like you're holding the sword yourself. Because of how well combat is crafted, having good skills means the game rewards you. There's not much replayability. You can try playing as a mage or thief type character, but there's so much focus on melee and bows you'll end up playing as a warrior anyway. The levels are also too linear. Overall, 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												The M&M series is primarily either an old-school, pen-and-paper style dungeon crawler, or a card game. Meanwhile, Dark Messiah is an oddity; it's a first-person action RPG in the Source engine, of all things! Picture Half-Life 2 with swords and sorcery instead of guns and robots, and you'll have a good idea of what this game plays like. Going into this title, I did not expect much. I knew it was from Arkane Studios, the same folks who delivered the excellent Dishonored, but all the same I was not prepared to fall in love with the game.The StoryMost certainly Dark Messiah's weakest aspect. You play as Sareth, an apprentice serving under the wizard Menelag. Your master has sent you to deliver some sort of artifact to a friend in a far off city, but has transported a woman into your conciousness to be your guide for mysterious reasons. Xana is pretty much a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ version of Cortana from Halo. You'll either tolerate her character, or outright despise her. Once you actually get to your destination, stuff hits the fan and you're thrust into a campaign to defeat an evil Necromancer. There are quite a few plot twists along the way. The biggest will probably be obvious to you, but I can guarantee there are plenty of left-field ones. The question is... will you even care enough to, well, care about what happens? 6/10The GameplayAhhh, now here's Dark Messiah's shining beacon of awesomeness. I'm going to be blunt about this one, straight out of the gate: Dark Messiah has the greatest first-person combat I've experienced in a game. The guys at Arkane are wizards when it comes to first-person animations; everything is incredibly silky smooth and satisfying to witness and interact with. As you progress through the game, you'll be rewarded Skill Points which you can then distribute as you please through two skill trees. There's no skill that will drastically change up how you play; just some generic "More HP" or "Slightly Bigger Fireball". Still, it works. You can also get some skill points by finding certain secret objectives within the world.Dark Messiah's level structure is not unlike Doom or Quake... Littered with clever secrets (Some I didn't find until my fifth or so playthrough!) filled with special loot like new armors and weapons. Using either a Sword & Shield, Dual-Daggers, Staves, Bows, or Magic, you'll slice and dice and stab and smash and burn and freeze and electrocute your way through hordes of Mercenaries, Orcs, Giant Spiders, Undead, and more. Though you can mash your attack button, that is rarely effective. The true combat is found using the various styles of power attacks. Not unlike the system found in Elder Scrolls, you'll preform different attacks based on which direction you are moving. From vertical swipes to long reaching stabs to hard-hitting slashes, you'll need to use every available move to defeat the very clever Orcs later on. Swords are nimble; the all-around weapon. They're capable of parrying foes, and you can even disarm by power-attacking while aiming at the hand. Daggers are lightning fast. They chop up foes before they can get a swing in, and they are capable of instant kills against unaware and fleeing enemies. Staves lack damage, but in smart hands they are the most powerful in the game. They can strike multiple foes at once, and blows to the head almost always stun instantly, leaving the foe extremely vulnerable to being kicked off their feet and into traps and the like. Bows work like you'd expect; headshots instantly kill unaware enemies. Once you get the skill that makes you draw faster and a secret unlimited quiver, it's possible to go bow-only, most definitely.Magic requires a lot of skill to use effectively. Sure, you have your standard fireballs and lightning bolts and freeze spells, but in my experience it is just too difficult to use solely these in combat. You'll need to be crafty; turn enemies against each other with a mind-control spell, shrink enemies to the size of mice, and lay traps near instant-killing spike-walls in the environment. About a third of the way through the game, you'll find the Rope Bow. Truly an inventive tool that I would adore seeing in another game. Near useless in combat, this weapon is instead used to navigate the environment; firing at any wooden structure above you will release a dangling rope you can climb and jump from! This one simple tool drastically changes up the level structure from there-on, and gives room for some dastardly secret nooks and crannies.Admittedly, it does take quite a while to get used to how the game works. But I guarantee you... when it all clicks, you'll be saying "Holy smokes! This is gosh-dang-diddly-dum AWESOME!" 10/10The Art and the SoundIf you've seen any sort of high fantasy movie, show, comic, or game, you've seen everything in Dark Messiah before. There's nothing visually that is truly original or outstanding. Admittedly, the super weapons later on have some great designs and one of the final levels is a big palette cleanser after hours of trudging through a boring ol' cave system. The environment, the enemies... it's all generic as possible. Thankfully, the sound is a fair bit better. The clang of metal against metal and swooshes of air as swords tear through it are top-notch and really bring a little extra bit of immersion. You'll probably get sick fast of the early Mercenary enemies who seem to always begin a fight with "Hey, pal!", but the later gruffness of Orcs and Goblins and the like feel a fair bit more threatening. 8/10The ReplayabilityBetween the many different styles of equipment available, the extremely harsh skill point limit, and the myriad of secrets to be found in every corner, you'll definitely want to play this beast more than once. The average first playthrough will probably take 12-15 hours. There are multiple endings, but trust me; you won't be replaying just to see these. The addictiveness of the combat is far more a reason to do so than the plot. 9/10In SummaryDark Messiah came out in 2006, and I played it in 2014. I was WOWed by it, and found myself playing it over five times before getting bored. I legitimately count it among one of my favorite games now. Well worth the low price of admission these days!Story: 6/10Gameplay: 10/10Art and Sound: 8/10Replayability: 9/10Total: 8.3/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2012
												The Good: Great visuals and voice acting, decent story, fun deep combat, lots of upgrades to get, tons of items to useThe Bad: Little in variety of enemy types, very linear, combat is tedious after awhile, semi-poor level design, HL2 engine is starting to look oldBefore I start here Dark Messiah suffered bad reviews because of all the terrible bugs that launched with the game. now that 2 1/2 years have passed Dark Messiah's bugs have been pretty much been ironed out and you now have a pretty fun action RPG. Before I start explaining the game DM uses the Half-Life 2 engine so you can expect some wonderful graphics and effects. DM uses the HL2 engine very well, but the engine is a bit supped up so you'll need a fairly beefy rig to run this game. If you computer was being pushed with HL2 then your computer will have a hard time running this game. I also have to mention that DM felt a lot like Oblivion Lite in the sense that it is set in Medieval times, melee combat is first person, and the art style is a little like Oblivion (not as unique of course).You play as a young protagonist named Sareth and you must stop the evil Arantir from using the Skull Crystal and bringing the Dark Messiah back to life. You have a choice to either stop him yourself or let the Dark Messiah live on. The story is actually fairly interesting and will keep you on the edge throughout this 15-20 hour adventure. Now DM is a linear RPG (it's not free roaming like Oblivion), but makes up for it with a intricate combat system. You have about 30-40 different item slots and you can carry things from health, mana, weapons, magic etc. As you progress through the game you will earn skill points for completing objectives and you can upgrade a variety of things from endurance, health, stealth, archery skill, learn new skills such as heal, fire arrow, freeze, sanctuary etc. There's a lot to learn and you won't upgrade 100% in a play through. You can either concentrate on being a Knight, Mage, or Archer or just go down the middle.There are a variety of unique weapons you can pick up throughout the adventure such as the awesome rope bow (shoot an arrow at any wood overhanging and a rope will come down), ice staffs, flame swords, poison daggers, and even a cool electricity shield that stuns enemies when they attack you. Now there are no shops where you can buy things so everything has to be picked up throughout the world. This keeps the action constantly going, but will disappoint people who are used to having stores in their RPGs.Combat consists of left clicking for your basic attack, but if you hold it down you do a Power Strike and whether or not you strafe, move forward, or backward will determine whether it's a side swipe, impale, or overhead strike. This can let you easily dodge attack and quickly strike back. You can use the right mouse button to block (and when you get the ability) left clicking to knock enemies back. Hit enough bad guys and you'll get your adrenaline bar up and this results in a gory slow-mo instant kill. This applies to all weapons and each of them have their own unique advantages to them. You have a kick button and this is great when you are on a ledge so you can just kick them off. Every so often you'll find spike beds on walls you can impale enemies on, also you'll find traps that can be kicked down to crush enemies.While the combat is really fun and you can do a lot with it; it will get repetitive after about half way through unless you use different weapons and toss things up. Every so often you'll find a blacksmith room where you can add bars of metal and forge your own weapons. Now when it comes to enemies there aren't to many of them (knights, undead, spiders, necromancers, evil demons) and that's about it. They are mixed up a lot, but you still can get bored of them after awhile.Every so often, though, you will get a great boss fight and these are huge creatures that require key items in the environment to kill them. These are pretty awesome and are very satisfying to take down. My biggest complaint must be the level design. A lot of times you won't find most of the hidden secret areas since they aren't even in places you'd remotely think they'd be in. There will be times you'll wonder around for over 30 minutes in the same place wondering where to go and this has to do with poor level design. The levels are very linear, most of the time dark, and really hard to navigate. Other than this Dark Messiah is a pretty good game, and you can even get it off Steam for $10! I highly recommend Dark Messiah to any action RPG fan.~Score: 8/10
