number of helpful: 4 of 42 people (10%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												At first I found this game rather enjoyable. It introduces alot of very interesting and unique concepts along the way, and item progression, as well as skill progression, actually matter quite a bit in this game. The main pitfalls (heh...) of this title are the mechanics, the physics engine. Enemies are tough to kill in combat, even if you tool yourself out with the best equipment possible, the game is brutally difficult. As such, many just resort to ranged combat, and trick the AI into getting stuck, so they can peg them with dozens of arrows. Main issues I encountered were such: Getting lost again and again, which I realised was partly due to several progression bugs which prevent key doors from opening. The level layout does tend to make everything sort of blend in, so figuring out just which corridor contains the identical looking wooden door you need to go through does happen. The rope bow/arrow, well before the latest Croft game and other titles empoyed it, is quite fun, until you start floating through walls while climbing ropes, because the physics engine was not programmed to deal with this vital game mechanic. The number of times I died whilst trying to do the fiddliest of tricky platforming (which as always, in a first person game, is just an awful idea from the start), due to the rope intersecting with a chunk of rock, which caused me to noclip out of the level... It gets frustrating very quickly. Finally, the magic in this game feels utterly flat. Fireballs hit enemies as though you just threw a small water balloon at them. Lightning appears to have the same effect as assaulting your enemy with a particularly wet piece of paper. There was absolutely no appeal to using magic in this game except as a means to use the mana I have anyway. If you really want to try it, nothing I say is going to stop you, but otherwise i'd say leave this game where it belongs, in the past.

number of helpful: 6 of 52 people (12%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
 Originally posted on July 11, 2009 Dark Messiah of Might and magic is a truly disappointing game. From the clunky controls to the frustratingly simple combat, the core game mechanics are boring, and the presentation is quite shabby to boot.Graphics- While some of the game's graphics can look pretty good, the overall effects are very uneven. Especially the game's more open areas look absolutely atrocious in comparison to other source games, as low res textures and bad backdrops abound.Sound- I found the sound design to be generic and not really anything special, although it did the job. The voice acting was pretty bad.Gameplay- The hack and slash mechanics with magic mixed in work much better in other titles that mix these dynamics, but for some reason Dark Messiah features a terribly frustrating control scheme and nonsensical combat mechanics that often feature your character taking damage full seconds after the enemy blows have been deflected. Button mashing combined with circle strafing led me to the most success when playing this game. In short, the gameplay, enemy, weapon and skill systems are pretty generic and do not provide for a satisfying experience.In addition to these concerns, the story is very very dull, providing no narrative flow or any kind of imperative to your actions.Overall, I'd say Dark Messiah is a sad example of low-budget game development gone wrong.

number of helpful: 8 of 59 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												This game is a combination of an action game with some RPG and magic elements. It seems to be very, very interesting.BUT.Could this game be any more harder? It's so hard it's almost ridiculous. I never was able to even finish the first level, even on Easy difficulty. Already the first enemies you encounter are like boss battles. I mean, even with bow and arrow an enemy takes about 5 to 10 shots before dying. A sneaky shot from behind to the head from behind doesn't deal any more damage.This is ridiculous.Additional to that comes the somewhat extremely clunky, not responsive controls. It's just plain awful and frustrating to play.The levels are designed to provide unique ways to kill an enemy, like kicking them into spikes / over the railing or destroying some planks which hold some barrels. This seems to be the ONLY way to succeed in this game, since a direct confrontation is pure suicide. Further problem is: Moving your character seems to be too stiff and not responsive and the back-steps are so tiny you're constantly being attacked.In conclusion for me, this game is way too hard, clunky and therefore no fun at all. I really tried it on Easy difficulty several times with different approaches and even on this setting its unplayable. For hardcore gamers or those who get the right tactic this might be a challenge but for gamers who just want some casual fun now and then, not a good choice.Update: Curiosity made me cheat - so I activated the God Mode, gave myself about 300 skill points and put everything to the maximum. I have to say: Good thing I didn't play this game the normal way so the disappointment came rather short. The visual effects and presentation of the spells like fireball or lightning bolt (both are fired through your hands) are looking, feeling and sounding very, VERY uninspired and boring.Don't buy it. And for the haters: Just respect another person's opinion. It's not that hard ;)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												This game...it needs to win the underrated game of the universe award.  Apparently went it first released, it was hampered with bugs and over shadowed by games like Oblivion. It is a Source Engine based game that plays very much like a combination of Thief and Half Life controls/combat.  It uses chapters/missions similar to both of those games as well.  It isn't open world but that won't bother you because there is plenty of loot hidden in secret areas for you to find.  It also starts off a bit rough with a hard to understand story and uninteresting at the time, plus the combat is difficult until you get new skills/weapons.  The combat in this game is so well done, especially for a game this old.  Most people say that if Elder Scrolls had this combat, they would be the best games ever made.  You'll have so much fun kicking enemies into spikes, fire, off stairs and using the many types of weapons you find along the way.  You even get to forge a few weapons.  Once you get past the first few chapters the story and gameplay really get great. I highly suggest playing on Hard mode because it forces you to use the various methods of fighting within the environment well.  You can activate traps laced within rooms like cutting ropes on swining objects, throwing oil on the ground and lighting enemies on fire, etc.  This game was worth every penny and I can't wait to finish it.Pros- Brilliant Combat System (super fun)- Variety of weapons to use and loot- Challenging Difficulties- Interesting Environments- Great Inventory and Skill System- Interactive Environments and SecretsCons- Mission based - Not Open World (plenty to explore though)- Story is bland at times- Steep learning curve- Unbalanced beginning- Slightly outdated and a few bugs remain (not the spiders)Score 9/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 9, 2013
												Right off the bat, Dark Messiah makes me question the simplistic nature of all combat in the Elder's Scrolls games. One thing is clear, though. Dark Messiah is a PC game, meant for gamers rather than mainstream turkies (gobble gobble!).Comparisons aside, this game has its moments but the AI is rather simplistic. Combine this with highly linear mapping and progression, and you have something very close to a late 90's-early 2000's, relic. Still, the distinction between the "classes" is well done. Magic, however, is feeble through most of the game without certain gameplay "tweaks". Typical really, as most devs have little vision for such things. Once you get a certain upgrade, however, you become untouchable. That's abstinent, rudimentry balancing if I ever saw it. The main problem lies with the adrenaline system and why magic had to be tied to it.Like most medieval-based games of this nature, Dark Messiah is catered primarily towards fans of swords, shields, and gimmicky action. I will say they did a good job of it, though. Progression and mapping may be simple, but the environment itself can be a lethal weapon. Magic may be feeble, but it's done just well enough to be enjoyable.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												No witty intro this time. Is it a good game or bad game, that's the real question here.Story/Design: The story is as much as you'd expect from a chapter based RPG Like game. You play as Sareth, the usual main protagonist of any RPG, he's not much during cutscenes but likeable enough. Unfortunately, the main plot is not the highlight of Dark Messiah, the plot is predictable, the plot twists are recognized from a mile away, and just not all that interesting. Is that a bad thing? Not really, you don't need the best story to make a great game, but it could have used a bit less clichés and more original ideas. The ending(s) do it a bit of justice, but not by much. Overall the story is just a bit too bland for me to enjoy besides the last few stages, and only slightly memorable if you look at the endings. Design wise, it's what'd you expect for a late 2006 game. Luckily it's made with the Source Engine so at least it has some decent looking details from then, but not everything is top quality obviously. Nothing hinders it, and it can hold up still for a few things, besides a few NPC designs of the humans. Unfortunately there's no real modding community or big graphic overhauls on this game as of this review, so you're stuck with the graphics. But again, it's not a flaw against the game. Gameplay/Mechanics: I'll start by saying Dark Messiah of Might & Magic has THE BEST first person RPG combat I have ever seen. Unlike Oblivion/Skyrim as you constantly spam your attack button hoping to kill them at first before they kill you, the combat is much more strategic and can vary depending on the situation. It's an RPG like experience, so you can be a few different kinds of "classes" I'll put them in. Mage, Archer, Rogue, and Warrior. Standard of course, but each have their strengths in this combat system, it's unfortunate I cannot put into words how well and fluid the combat is with each class type, as it's one of those systems where you need to try for yourself and see it's not just another clunky button mashing system like in the Scrolls games. Traps and environmental hazards are plentiful, and ragdoll physics are just fun to mess with during fights, as kicking Orcs into a wall of spikes or off a cliff has never been so satisfying. (Or kicking a bird on a beach, I mean why not?) The A.I. is surprisingly smart and can be ruthless if you're reaching your breaking point, some say it's cheap and the A.I. is way too tough, but I'd prefer a challenge over a way too easy game experience where I don't die at all. They do not have health bars either, which I believe is a nice touch, as if they're injured enough they'll plea for their lives of limp away in agony and try to escape or get help. There's not a specific class either, you'll be needing to use all of your tricks to take down enemies, with stealth as best you can being very effective and immensely rewarding, to long ranged assault on unsuspecting goblins, or magic against non-humanoid creatures. It's never just one class throughout the game, which can help make each level feel fresh. Overall, what is this game? Does it have a compelling and memorable story? No. Memorable characters? Not really, unless you're a pervert and wanting to remember all the slightly nude women. (Why have that?) Best level design? Not really, unless it's well placed birds for you to kick, then that's a plus. What it does have going for it is the combat, the gameplay, the A.I, the kind of fights you'll remember a few years down the road when playing some other RPG with awful combat ... not naming any names. Some games don't need to have a good narrative or plot going for it, as the gameplay can make the game. It's not perfect, but it's not bad either. Only if they made this a more open world like Oblivion and keep the combat like this, it'd be my favorite RPG. (One day...) Overall rating: 7.5/10+Best combat out of any RPG I've played+Smart A.I. +Interesting hidden items! +Can punt kick a bird off a beach.-Bland story/characters-Non memorable protagonist or plot-Mixed level design

content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												NOT always easy to set up on any OS other than Windows XP (not impossible, but they made a few odd design choices that Vista and 7 don't like much), this is a fantastic game. One of the first to use the Source engine, you step into the role of a wizard's apprentice and go treking through your round-of-the-mill fantasy setting. Conspiracies and such follow, but suffice to say that the game's emphasis on physics and a realistic first-person perspective (you ride into town in a wagon, which makes for a really nice intro) more than make up for its short-comings. I learned that the third or forth time I impaled a grunt on a spike by kicking him off of the roof, only after first ramming his head into the roof itself several times. Violent, oh yes, but plenty fun.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												Ah, Dark Messiah. A wonderful game! I had a lot of fun with this one.Graphics:Source engine. Sharp textures nice physics. There isn't much to say about it really. The graphics look fine and they are holding up well to this day. Oh there is one thing, you are able to see your own feet. I think this is important, it somehow adds a lot of "friction" to the world (think: Arx Fatalis)Sound:Okay. Has oomph. Little music in this game - which is a good thing (think: Dark Souls).Story:You are a hero on a quest to save some part of some world. I don't think there were any rats in a basement to kill, but there is a succubus manifested in your head that'll talk to you occasionally, resulting in some funnily greasy moments. It's nothing special all in all - but the succubus gives it a decent twist.Gameplay:This is where Messiah shines. Luckily - who gives a damn about graphics and story in an ego-fantasy-rpg-hackfest? Well, lay aside the rpg, there isn't much roleplaying to do apart from some character development. This character development will decide whether you'll be casting, shooting arrows or close combating your way through the world, and with the given physics and environmental dangers in level design this gives for some really awesome fights. I love the fights! I love the kick, i love the brutal finishing moves and i love the kick. Yea, you can kick people off high places in this game, and you'll never grow tired of that since there are about a million ledges to kick people, orcs and other monsters off of... of? The combat is awesome, like seriously. It's like Skyrim done right! It's fast paced, it's gritty, it's evil and it'll make you feel like a real Badass Dark Messiah of Might and Magic! You should get this game just because of that. That's it. Start, and don't stop playing until you get to the Orc village. If you hold through until then, you will start loving the game. But yea, until then everything is weird. Combat mechanics feel odd and the game starts slow and boring.I beat this game annually, because it's cool.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												Ah, Dark Messiah. A wonderful game! I had a lot of fun with this one.Graphics:Source engine. Sharp textures nice physics. There isn't much to say about it really. The graphics look fine and they are holding up well to this day. Oh there is one thing, you are able to see your own feet. I think this is important, it somehow adds a lot of "friction" to the world (think: Arx Fatalis)Sound:Okay. Has oomph. Little music in this game - which is a good thing (think: Dark Souls).Story:You are a hero on a quest to save some part of some world. I don't think there were any rats in a basement to kill, but there is a succubus manifested in your head that'll talk to you occasionally, resulting in some funnily greasy moments. It's nothing special all in all - but the succubus gives it a decent twist.Gameplay:This is where Messiah shines. Luckily - who gives a damn about graphics and story in an ego-fantasy-rpg-hackfest? Well, lay aside the rpg, there isn't much roleplaying to do apart from some character development. This character development will decide whether you'll be casting, shooting arrows or close combating your way through the world, and with the given physics and environmental dangers in level design this gives for some really awesome fights. I love the fights! I love the kick, i love the brutal finishing moves and i love the kick. Yea, you can kick people off high places in this game, and you'll never grow tired of that since there are about a million ledges to kick people, orcs and other monsters off of... of? The combat is awesome, like seriously. It's like Skyrim done right! It's fast paced, it's gritty, it's evil and it'll make you feel like a real Badass Dark Messiah of Might and Magic! You should get this game just because of that. That's it. Start, and don't stop playing until you get to the Orc village. If you hold through until then, you will start loving the game. But yea, until then everything is weird. Combat mechanics feel odd and the game starts slow and boring.I beat this game annually, because it's cool.

Posted: July 14, 2015
												When I first got this game, I found it in the local GAME store when I was younger I decided it looked cool and bought it. Then this game became one of my best old-school fantasy experiences I've ever had when I was younger and stupider, This game changed my viewing of other games with me learning about the story and experiencing the immense abilities the game has to offer instead of just playing the game for the sake of it. This game gave me creative ways in which to eliminate my foes which was one of the best things about the combat within the game. The atmosphere of the game is astonishing and realistic, also fitting for the settings and multiple locations of the Game. And the interesting story is easy to follow just by listening to Cutscenes in the game. Dark Messiah is although a game which has set paths in which you HAVE to take to progress within the game, it still has many areas which allow you to drive away from just the objective and get better items. Since this game had so many oppurtunities in it, I have played this game's singleplayer more than usual about 15 times or more, the first 3 times I played and completed this game was the story choices (Bad, Good.), class selection (Theif, Mage, Warrior) And the rest was for the whole nostalgia effect and just to see how fast I can complete the game or just play-through it to just have a nice old-school experience. I would reccommend people to buy this game and keep the game in their libary just to have it as a side-game to play it for bordeom or story choices, despite it being an Old Game. Great Game 10/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
												I bought this game almost on Day 1 back in 2006 - Steam seemed to have reset my progress during an update, so I gave it another run-though.This is a great game, very underrated and immensely fun - albeit flawed in a few areas.The graphics are amazing for 2006 standards, Source is used very well, the environments are beautiful, the atmosphere great and the models are also decent. The game is BRUTAL, finisher moves, burning corpses, beheadings, turn limbs etc.The gameplay... oh dear, how do I even describe this. "Might&Magic" is about right, I'd say. On my first playthrough, I decided to go full-on Warrior (usually I'd go for a mix, paladin-ish thing), and it was IMMENSELY fun, the combat is great once you get the hang of it, although I'm sorry I didn't play it on hard, because once you get beefed up a little, slaying enemies is a bit too unchallenging. I think I died maybe twice the whole campagin during combat. When you get the Lightning Shield and the Dragonborn sword, well, it just gets ridiculous.On my second playthrough, I chose a full-on Mage (combat mage, staff and all) and while I was a bit whimpy at first, by the end, I was even MORE powerful than a Warrior. Mana-sucking staff and Sanctuary=god mode, basically. I wasn't new to the game though, so that helped, but still, if you're going for a narrow, "one-trick-pony" build, perhaps play on Hard right off the bat, otherwise you might wade through enemies like dust.The reason why I said "Might and Magic is about right" is that I tried doing the whole Stealth/Thief thing, and more often times than not, it falls a bit flat. It's either too easy (really obvious ledges and rafters to avoid enemies) or too hard (open areas where you can't really be sneaky at all), and the inconsistent Stealth meter doesn't help - you can be "invisible" in plain torchlight or completely visible in total darkness; go figure.  The story is... alright, it has a few twists, and the game has 4 endings, depending on which woman you choose to leave alive and what you do at the very end. It's alright, but to me, it was really corny, though it wasn't necessarily the bad kind of corny either. Oh, and the voice acting is pretty cringe-worthy, it's just soooo emPHATIC and exaggerated to death. Nothing like the subtle delivery of Half-Life's Alyx or Barney, hell, even Dr. Mossman wasn't as annoying as most of the characters in this game. Not driving an Orc Cleaver through Leanna's face requires some serious self-control, believe me.One more (rather major) gripe: it does have a tendency to glitch/crash at times. The Rope Bow close to flat surfaces is a classic example, then there are random crashes, overall, it's not the most stable of games, so save often.All in all, it's Skyrim/Oblivion without the overbearing world and clunky combat system. It's a non-stealthy Thief. It deserves your attention and at the very LEAST, two playthroughs.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2011
												GREAT storyline that let me feel like my actions fit the storyline my character was a part of, and other characters within the storyline act wonderfully and in meangful ways.  Graphics are decent and the game engine (Source) works as expected, environments are in general pleasant but can be confusing.Now to the best parts -- The combat WORKS.  Slashes have noticeable impact upon your foes, magic / archery / stealth all work well in addition to the standard melee fighting.  Environmental hazards abound and are a joy to use, as are the various special strikes and methods of dispatching your foes.Another good part -- The platforming WORKS.  See those knee-high barrier walls and neck height ledges you just can't seem to scale in other games?  You can in this one!  A big climbing mechanic in the Rope Bow allows for great platforming and exploring element which the game fully realizes and rewards the player for.This is a Fantasy FPS-Melee game DONE WELL.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Dark Messiah has one of the better combat mechanics in a game to date. In many ways this game is absolutely fantastic despite its problems. It still looks stellar even though the graphics  won't compare well with today's standards. It is really funny, I mean the ragdolls and physics in this game is just hilarious at times (perhaps not intented though).But it is also frustrating, and with a forgetable story full of shameful clichés. Despite high production value in cut-scenes and music, the voice acting makes you shudder of embarrassment, and you wonder who this story was written by, and targeted to. I can only come up with 8 year boys who know nothing about the other sex. This game could easily be used as an example of shameful tropes and predictable storylines in videogames. Feminist or not, most people would find the story quite horrid.Perhaps one of the biggest annoyances is that even though the game looks and feels great, and runs with no problems on today's machines, the engine just feels a little clunky. You miss a lot with your sword and your character feels a clumbsy. It doesn't feel like the source engine is the greatest choice for this type of game. At the same time the physics and ragdolls are just the whole point of this game. The game constantly encourage you to use objects,in your surroundings, and kick things around. There are many way to get rid of your foes that does not involve your fighting skills. Kicking foes off from cliffs just never gets old.The game gives many options of fighting, but in my mind going full sword combat is the only real way to enjoy the game because it is easier that way, and probably the most fun - It just becomes bonkers. The worst style is to do a little of everything because there is not enough skill points for just one style. This is too bad because you probably want to try the all the fighting options the first play-through, but it is better to play through several times, specializing. You might find the game too hard the first time, but I promise it will get easier as you understand how it works. What can cause a lot of frustration is the reach of both you and the foes. This will result in you getting hit a lot because you will strike too late, thinking the foes are not close enough.What is really great is that it is a game you really learn to master, you don't just level up. In fact "levelling up" happens at fixed points and is not based on how you play. A great way to replay the game is to try something completely different which really changes gameplay and provides many other creative ways to get rid of your foes. I did find the stealth/thief option the least interesting even though I love stealth games. Speaking of thief, this games will feel very familiar if you like the earlier thief games, for example there is a rope-arrow which really makes this game much more enjoyable. Another similar game is dishonored, but Dark Messiah is better in that you won't get punished for being creative. Dishonored is ultimately a much better game though, but not as ridicoulous. This ridiculousness is one of Dark Messia's strong sides and a strong reason to play through.Dark Messiah is an old game but the graphics are still enjoyable and you visit many great locations. The source engine gives lots of life and depth ot the game. The fighting mechanics are really good even though the hitboxes are rather confusing at times. When you master the mechanics well it feels quite awesome.I do reckomend it. It runs really well, has great ideas and fun mechanics that will make you laugh. It is often dirt cheap as well. Just don't care too much about the story. This game is about mechanincs, not about story (Even though story is important, it is not necessary for a good game. A good story and horrible mechanics is a bigger problem in my mind - like BioShock infite for exaple). But is not hard and serious as dark souls.

Probably one of the best games I have played.I definitely recommend buying this game, and I emplore that you grab this if it is on sale.I really enjoyed playing this although the ending was a bit of a letdown because I didn't get to do anything after completing the "task" I had been working toward all game.  I would really have liked to have a small amount of content after the goal of the game had been completed so I could interact with my "companion", or see a bit of what happened instead of a short cutscene. There are 4 possible endgame cutscenes, 2 for completing the game with Leanna, and 2 for completing the game with Xana. Playthroughs will probably take you between 4-10 hours depending on whether or not you like to rush, or you like to search everything and find secrets. I had issues with the game crashing but for the most part it seems to had been an issue with the "Global Settings" under my Nvidia control panel settings conflicting with the game settings.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												A personal anecdote from yours truly.I was a young'un during the heyday of EverQuest, and later WoW.  Too young to muster the resources to see those games in action, let alone play them.  (Yes, that means videos too -- dialup, motherf**ker, have you used it?)  So I was left to simply imagine the majesty of these virtual worlds.  Mind you, I wasnt raised on Dungeons & Dragons, frankly I found Tolkienesque fantasy a tired premise before I even knew the name 'Tolkien'.  But gaming was the new frontier of entertainment, and the idea of entering a bona fide fantasy realm set my little mind ablaze with possiblity.Maybe I 'missed the wave' with MMORPGs.  Or maybe my years with Counter-Strike took the sheen off multiplayer gaming.  But by the time I finally saw WoW for myself, I couldn't care less.  I'll gladly take five minutes of deathmatch over a month of MMO banality.But then I randomly found this game, Dark Messiah.  And I was amazed at how it looked and played exactly like the MMO fantasy I had imagined all those years.  Combat wasnt just a mathematical abstraction, the level design looked like a coherent living world (even though, ultimately, its a linear FPS affair) and the art direction made the most out of everything to immerse you into it's world.  This was the fantasy adventure I wanted, but didnt get, from MMORPGs.The only thing missing is the multiplayer, but thats a fair trade IMO.  Pubbies ruin everything anyway...

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												When I first got this game, I found it in the local GAME store when I was younger I decided it looked cool and bought it. Then this game became one of my best old-school fantasy experiences I've ever had when I was younger and stupider, This game changed my viewing of other games with me learning about the story and experiencing the immense abilities the game has to offer instead of just playing the game for the sake of it. This game gave me creative ways in which to eliminate my foes which was one of the best things about the combat within the game. The atmosphere of the game is astonishing and realistic, also fitting for the settings and multiple locations of the Game. And the interesting story is easy to follow just by listening to Cutscenes in the game. Dark Messiah is although a game which has set paths in which you HAVE to take to progress within the game, it still has many areas which allow you to drive away from just the objective and get better items. Since this game had so many oppurtunities in it, I have played this game's singleplayer more than usual about 15 times or more, the first 3 times I played and completed this game was the story choices (Bad, Good.), class selection (Theif, Mage, Warrior) And the rest was for the whole nostalgia effect and just to see how fast I can complete the game or just play-through it to just have a nice old-school experience. I would reccommend people to buy this game and keep the game in their libary just to have it as a side-game to play it for bordeom or story choices, despite it being an Old Game. Great Game 10/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 18, 2010
												Amazingly fun singleplayer action. From beheading enemies in a slow-motion moment to tossing corpses at goblins! The combat in this game is intense and keeps you on your toes. Just as any fps would except you're using swords, bows, magic and my favorite: daggers! I would like to say that they could have added a wider variety of weaponry but with what they have, it's fantastic! The environment is your weapon, too, if you know how to use it ;)Even the story line is enthralling. It might seem a little scatter brained and linear but I have to say it is very original! They incorporated a few aspects I never thought about (being a story-minded person). I enjoyed it very much.I would advice anyone and everyone to play the demo to give it a try!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												I have been aquainted with this game long ago, when I was actually reading gaming magazines.(lacking internet around that time) One thing that stuck to me recently is the sandbox combat that spices some situations, although the physics of of some situations makes it a bit awkward and sometimes it looks just too forced to even seem realistic. Melee combat, however, is truly impressive. Making use of the smooth character movement(strafing, jumping, power strikes), you can perform effective combat manouvers and unpexpected turnouts makes it even more spectacular.( ex. that moment when you use a power strike on an Orc charging you and both of you cross swords, making it a click masher before it gets decieded who is disarmed). The magic system could have used a bit more adaptability to the already flexible character tree that you can develop up to the epilogue of the game. However, magic itself serves as a very useful tool in some situations.( ex. unlocking the cells of prisoners with telekinesis so that the Necromancer doesn't see you and goes Darth Vader on your neck)All in all, the game has quite decent a storyline, mood and visuals( especially for it's age) and I can honestly say that I have encountered only a few glitches. It may not cater to some modern gamers but those of you who are more old school will find this game quite pleasant and memorable experience.

Posted: June 19, 2016
												So one day.... I was surfing the web on what are some good steam games to buy. I came across a comment on reddit that said "Dark Messiah of Might and Magic" and then some others commented on that saying that, THAT game is the "best". I then decide to look it up on the store on steam, I watch some videos on it, looked at the comments and decided to give it a try. I went ahead and bought the game and fired up single player. I've got to admit, it's a pretty fun game. Even though I havn't played a lot, I did enjoy the time i already played. I then came to find out that the multiplayer is dead. I was a little upset at first, but then I showed the game to my friend. He really wanted the game after i showed him, but he didnt have any money. So me, being the generous guy I an, gifted him it and we occasionally 1v1 in multiplayer whenever we feel like it. I definitly recommend this game to any one who is even a little interested in picking it up.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												This game is simply amazing once it gets going. While the combat and movement may seem a bit clunky at first, you quickly get the hang of it and realize what all it offers. Many games say they deal environmental damage, but Dark Messiah is the only one I know of that continues to offer alternative routes for just about every thing you can possibly do. While you are not technically in an open world, the large levels with a plethora of secrets and alternate routes give you the illusion of one.  I'm still finding secrets several play throughs later. If you like first person action/adventure games, particularly those like Thief, you should definitely give this game a try.

												A pretty good RPG all around. Dark MessiahInteresting game in which arkane studios managed to create a mix of RPG/adventure game with good level design and excellent gameplay mechanics but the game is mostly action oriented despite the existence of the stealth route that is manageable ( if you engage in close direct combat you have that feeling of "weight" in the actions made by mele weapons which they nailed perfectly ) - i played a combo build : twin daggers + stealth approach from "behind" :D ( i tried as much as possible to avoid direct contact - to be unseen, and to kill eventual enemies from "behind" ) - as a conclusion you can see the later refined development taking shape in the form of Dishonored years later :D

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												This is a deep action RPG with a heavy emphasis on a variety of combat choices, and one of the few games I've seen that does "character builds" properly. Except for the occasional unmodeled wall, the game looks good, and has great level design for what is really quite a linear experience.Really, the main focus is on the combat, which it does spectacularly, thanks to the best usage of the Source engine that I think I've ever seen, but the actual execution of the engine is where the game shows its two biggest faults, aside from my computer's language being changed to French every time I play the game.- Visual effects can often crowd the screen to the point that vision is annoyingly obstructed.- Enemies can sometimes get stuck on certain objects, making them cheap, easy targets.That's it. That's all I disliked. Everything else is golden.Last minute note: The multiplayer is kind of dead, unless you don't mind looking for private servers.

number of helpful: No ratings yet1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												The game shows the signs of age, but nonetheless a good remark about some aspects that RPGs usually don't take into account.Pros:+ Good gameplay, with a wide range of possible strategies to afford enemies;+ Environment can (must) be used; also, good stealth mechanism;+ Multiple endings: now we're all used to it, but back in the time it must have been awesome and it's right to give it the right credit.Cons:- Lack of secondary quests and lore - set aside the choices for the endings, the storyline is straightforward;- Few customization options for the character's skills;- Poor enemy IA, counterbalanced by high damage output - no way to be tank;- The story is nothing new under the sun.There might be other pros and cons, but the main ones are here. Recommended, for the nostalgic or the "collector" who wants to see with his eyes an RPG which gives importance to the environment (I'm both).

content:
Posted: December 29, 2011
												The singleplayer is a truly unique and (yes, in this case, the word fits) epic experience, it's a pity that the game is hard to mod and didn't ever get a sequel. Lot's of hack 'n slay fun with a combat system that may LOOK like Oblivion/Skyrim/..., but is superior and more fluent in any way. Don't expect too many RPG elements besides an inventory and a skill tree.The multiplayer is unpolished, unbalanced and barely resembles the singleplayer experience, though it can be insanely fun if you can gather enough friends to play it with, especially at LAN parties.

												A very under appreciated game. It has a bad rap because it was severely buggy when it was released and has no business being in the Might and Magic universe. The story is also laughably bad. The single most redeeming feature is the really well done combat. You can't just run in with your sword swinging. You have to use the environment and physics to your advantage. The spells are very powerful but have a large windup time.There's really no reason not to try it because the game is super cheap now. Just don't expect anything beyond the fun combat.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2012
												Though swords and magic settings are primarily used by rpgs, this game uses the setting for an action game. There are no choices, shops, or overworld. There is character customization in which gear you can equip, spells, if any, to use, and the like. Combat is fairly decent, with variety in weapons, swords, daggers, staves, and such. But the most fun you can have is seeing the ways in which you can cause environmental deaths by using your kick to knock enemies around. Whether it be spikes, cliffs, traps, or mixing it up by hitting them with a pot of oil, then lighting it, environmental deaths are often the funniest and most efficient ways to defeat your foes. At ten dollars, it's not a bad buy, but Steam has sales with it often enough, so pick it up then, and it will truly be worth it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
Dark Messiah of Might and Magic ReviewAhh such a classic game. I remember playing this on the xbox and spending countless hours finding different ways to kill enemies! Without further a due lets jump in shall we? Ill split this review into the following categories: gameplay, graphics, audio, and story.Gameplay/CombatProbably the most entertaining aspect of this game is the gameplay. It's first person with a very fluid feel to it. You play the game by picking from the skill trees (or putting points into multiple trees effectiely becoming a hybrid) and using weapons that correlate to that tree. Warriors use shields and sword, mages use staff, rogues use bows and daggers, etc. I played through the game as a rogue/warrior hybrid and gotta say it was fun as hell. The physics engine is hilarious, theres nothing like spartan kicking a ghoul over the castle walls. The game is not all that long which is fine because for what the game is trying to achieve the length was perfect. I could go on forever explaining the combos, power attacks, etc you can use but ill just use a bulleted list to give the highlights.  great physics fun traps to use against enemies simple skill system diverse ways to kill enemies=never bored short-medium length game. hidden areas to discover which give good weapons and some additional skill points. AudioHonestly not a whole lot to say here. The audio isnt anything special. Sound effects sound appropriate and the background tracks/combat music aren't especially exciting or annoying. For this part i'd just say "meh".GraphicsDecent graphics, some models and enemies looked a little neglected to some of the other characters but I suppose thats to be expected when you don't spend much time looking at them as you do punting them into a wall of spikes.If you want to know what I mean look at the cyclops and goblins in the game. Compared to orcs and humans they look lackluster but again im not going to sit here and rag on it like its a big deal this game is FUN.StoryOk so this part, in my opinion, was very well thoughtout. I won't spoil the main plot of the game as that would ruin some of the fun but do know you can essentially choose to be good or evil. Because of this "choice" system (there arent that many choices as say, dragon age) there are multiple endings which may add some replay value on top of the desire to want to play through again as a different class. It starts out simple and adds enough throughout the game to keep you interested. Its not AMAZING but it was cool and had a nice twist to it, albeit one that probably a lot of people will see coming. All in all, pretty good.Additional Notes-I did encounter some minor bugs here and there but nothing game breaking. Of particular annoyance was a sound bug in which the sound effect of flys near dead bodies would "follow" you around regardless of how far you got away from the body. A simple reload will solve this.-I played through two times to get the endings and i recommend your first time through just to play without much worry about secret areas and hidden items, then on your second playthough take the time to looks for the secret areas so you get cooler weapons/armor and more skill points.-SECRET AREAS ARE "NOT" required. You can easily beat this game with the weapons that drop from enemies/you find in your path way and youll have plenty of skill points to make your character into a decent hybrid or a focused badass.Id rate this game a 8.5/10. Plenty of fun and defintely worth the money if on sale!

												Awesome melee combat. While there are some RPG fragments, mostly with the advancement tree, what i really loved about Dark Messiah of Might and Magic is the awesome melee combat and the physics of it. The game is made by the Arx Fatalis creators, but it has little resembance to Arx Fatalis (something that many Arx fans disliked) and is much more action oriented. 												A highly underrated Action-RPG that kicks way more♥♥♥♥♥than most titles coming out nowadays. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												Dark Messiah is an interesting game which at times feels like some odd amalgam of Morrowind, Tomb Raider, and Thief. The levels are fairly linear but the overall locales and environments were interesting to explore regardless. However, my one complaint is that much of the game is played in pretty dark environments, dungeons, crypts, etc - but the brighter environments were more enjoyable. Overall though, the atmosphere and the unique graphics engine has kept the game fresh despite its age. The dialogue is merely so-so and the voice acting of the main character is bad. Nonetheless, this game has some really interesting moments and is full of good sword play and combat. I felt the use of the rope bow was overdone at times, but otherwise it was an innovative addition. Note that as the story progresses, you earn skill points which allows you to learn new abilities and improve basic stats - it is a very simple RPG addition into what is otherwise a first-person action adventure game.Prepare to battle orcs and dragons, jump from dangerous precipices, and kick your foes into spikes, flames, and off mountain tops.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												If you're looking for a game with excellent swordplay mixed with a good dose of magic, this is it. Unless you're well versed in the lore of the Might and Magic universe, you won't care much about the story. That said, it was engaging enough. In fact, it's not the story that'll keep you hooked but the gameplay. Enemies work as a team and if you play on hard, each encounter becomes a fight to the death. I can't stress enough how fleshed out the combat mechanics are in this game. Advice: Play on normal on your first playthrough. I started this game on hard and at one point, I simply couldn't proceed because it takes quite a lot of skill to fight each and every enemy. Not saying hard mode is unfair but if you don't have enough time to spare for video games, you won't like how difficult 'hard' mode is. Also, game has demon waifu.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2010
												A really great and terribly underrated game. It's a bit like Half-Life mixed with Oblivion, in that it has a linear story but RPG elements that allow you to build whatever kind of character you like, whether it be a swordfighter, sorcerer, assassain, or a combination of different abilities. Has great combat and bloody fatality-style moves that are always fun to do. It even has good multiplayer, which combines classed-based point capturing like TF2 with a per-round experience system that gives you greater abilities like in the single-player (although I don't know how many people are on the multiplayer anymore). A really fun game the whole way through, and a must-play for it's price.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												This is one of my favourite games of all time. I've played it lots of times, even before I bought it on Steam. How the metascore could be 72 is beyond me. Anyway, here's a list of advantages and disadvantages:con:-It has some technical difficulties sometimes-you will fight a lot of clones, all with the same voicesliterally nothing elsepro:-It has one of the best combat systems I know,-you can play it in many different ways, because--a: you can interact with the environment in so many ways, and--b: the skill system, which does not offer many skills, offers a few really powerful ones, so that you can quickly specialize significantly. Especially if you use the according items.-the level design is simply divine.-story is archetypal, but with brilliant cutscenes and very nice characters, given the relatively short time in which they appear.-the story is embedded in the Might and Magic universe, so it has a lot of background and many references to the stories in the Heroes of Might and Magic series.-the art design is great, it really feels like something different altogether and something very raw, gritty and realistic. So even now, years after the graphics are actually outdated, it still looks good. -the overall atmosphere is thrilling and tense in a way I do not experience often in video games.So, don't let the age or the low metascore fool you, this game gets 9.5/10

Posted: January 15, 2011
												A Great Fantasy Experience. This isnt your typical M&M. this is a Fantasy FPS at its best. Some say its not as good as Oblivion, and well, as a a Fantasy game its pretty good. Nice Leveling of skill points based on actions not kills, so there is no grinding. There is no over leveling either. Its a pretty balanced game. 7.5/10PS. it is old Source. There is a mem leak on high end systems that reduce performance to Nil. so Dual/Quad core, DX10/DX11 and W6/7 = nearly impossible to play. to fix it I loaded everything on Very High, Vsync, and QS/QL often as a fresh load helped.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 22, 2011
												Probably one of my most replayed singleplayer games because of all the different ways you bring pain to the not so defenseless (and quite tough!) enemies. Wether it be outplaying them in the way of melee combat or simply being a lil bich and chucking a barrel right in their face, this game offers many, MANY ways to play it with its huge replay value.Wanna be a spell-casting mage that still fights with swords with the occasional use of bows?Go right the hell ahead, there is absolutely no limitations that stop you from doing just that.The incredible versatility and depth of the combat system provides many etertaining ways to dispatch enemies. Learn ice magic and freeze your enemies. Discover that you can use said spell on the ground and create a patch of ice, watch and laugh your♥♥♥♥♥off as 5 orcs coming to chase you all slip on said ice and fall to their deaths. This is just one of the many past times you'll come to see in this gameThe game is built on the source engine and makes use of all the nice, juicy physics engine that we've all come to love over time. Pick up heavy objects and toss it at enemies which results in the enemy stumbling hilariously in whatever direction the object was thrown in. Use your mighty Duke Nukem boot to send a baddy flying down a crevice or to send them into the many VERY  convinently traps.The RPG elements certainly blend well with the game, with the skill trees being flexible and many of the skills being quite handy. You are also able to spread your skills however you please so it opens up many possibilities on different playstyles that will certainly not all be experienced in just one single playthrough.
